About

The goal of this project is to present the four Gospels (Jesus words and acts) in an attractive and easy to understand way.

The building blocks are events. Thus if an event is described by multiple authors then all of those descriptions are grouped and available in parallel. This grouping is called synoptic Gospels.

On top of this well-known synoptic grouping, the events are listed in chronological order mainly based on the thoughts shared on the website 4gospels.info⇱. There are many alterations regarding the timeline, however, the basic principle that organising the events based on feasts, has been greatly utilised. Time is referenced in weeks and clearly displayed throughout the document.

An interactive map helps in visualising the events in space. The location of the event visited for the last time is being highlighted on the map. Nothing proves more clearly the need of a map than that the events of "Jesus Helps A Non-Jewish Woman" (week 18-31) and "The Ten Lepers" (week 33) are both positioned elsewhere in the timeline in line with common sense and human capacities.

There are both overlappings and conflicts between parallel Gospels. For a smooth reading experience, wherever multiple author's descriptions are available, the most complete and logically sound writing has been ordered into the first position. These authors are displayed in [brackets]. Where completeness and logic could only be guaranteed by multiple authors, then an extra description has been created by merging verses together from these authors. The merge is strictly full-verse based. No verses have been partially picked ever. These merged descriptions are named [Default]. The merging is the reason for displaying verses with full reference (author, chapter, verse) instead of verse numbers only.

Connection

Chronological order can be made in more than one way. Merging verses of the same event from multiple authors in a way that they provide completeness and a smooth reading experience at the same time, is also not straightforward. Locations and reference week ranges are not always obvious either. Main titles, subtitles are also subjective. We can make the content of this site really good together only.

Should you want to discuss your observations or thoughts, please feel free to start or join a topic in this forum.

In case the nature of your say is private, you can get in contact via gospelsharmony@gmail.com

Copyrights

The chronological order is mainly based on thoughts shared on 4gospels.info⇱ which was inspired by Michael Rood's observations. However, no direct knowledge of Michael Rood's works influenced the content of this site.

The English version is the New Century Version® (NCV). Copyright © 2005 by Thomas Nelson, Inc.
Except chapter 'The Family History Of Jesus', which uses the Contemporary English Version (CEV) for brevity. Copyright © 1995 by American Bible Society.

The Hungarian version uses the Easy-to-Read Version (ERV-HU). Copyright © 2003, 2012 by World Bible Translation Center. With the following alterations:

  • Wherever word "spirit" is used in positive meaning, the "szellem" has been replaced by "lélek" in line with the Hungarian common sense. E.g.: szellemidézés, szelleműzés, szellemváros, but(!) lélekgondozás, lelkiismeret, lélekmentő, lélekvándorlás, a lelkére beszél,...

  • The family name of Maria Magdalene can be translated to Hungarian in two ways: someone from the village of Magdala or as a first name: "Magdolna". Wherever "from Magdala" is used it has been replaced by "Magdolna".

  • In ERV-HU, some verses are merged with dashed verse references (e.g. 12-13) in line with common sense and/or for better understanding. However, due to the operation of the web site builder program, the verses must be standalone. The separation has required some translation which uses either the same words as the original or if this was not possible then the words of the Hungarian New Translation (NT-HU), Copyright © 1975, 1990 Hungarian Bible Society.
